byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Jess Bidgood from Boston, Nicholas Fandos from Baltimore, Benjamin Mueller from New York and John Surico from Princeton, N.J.
byline.original: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS and DAVID W. CHEN

abstract: Ridership on the nation's Northeast Corridor rail sector has doubled over past 30 years, even as old and overloaded infrastructure has begun to wear out; corridor, which carries some 750,000 passengers each day on Amtrak and other commuter lines, has become subject to regular disruptions and delays that have left passengers exasperated; money for repairs and improvements has not been forthcoming amid partisan gridlock and accusations that Amtrak has neglected its infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The Northeast Corridor has doubled its ridership in the last 30 years as its old and overloaded infrastructure has begun to wear out.

headline.main: Aging Infrastructure Plagues Nation’s Busiest Rail Corridor
headline.print_headline: Trail of Frustration on Aging Northeast Corridor

snippet: The Northeast Corridor has doubled its ridership in the last 30 years as its old and overloaded infrastructure has begun to wear out.
